title: Modification to X-Axis Belt Tension Fork to allow cogged bearing for Startt

description.text:
I decided to change the idler bearings to flanged cogged idler bearings. I read somewhere that these cogged bearings run smoother with cogged belts than the stock smooth bearings, I purchased the following bearings from Amazon for $9 US delivered:

BIQU GT2 20Teeth 5mm Bore Aluminum Timing Belt Idler Pulley for 3D Printer 6mm Width Timing Belt (Pack of 5pcs)

www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01H3DNKYY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

These cogged idler bearings are wider than the stock bearings. The stock Y axis idler mount and the Y-axis belt tensioner mod designed by Bkult3 both use the huge spacing washers with the stock idler bearings. Removing the large spacing washers allows the flanged cogged bearing to fit perfectly.

The attached is a modification to the tensioner fork in the X-axis belt tension for Startt by Bkult3. It allows the wider flanged cogged idle bearing to fit. This is just a easy tweak to Bkult3 great design.

The tensioner mods of the X and Y axis work great and I thank Bkult3 for his effort.

I don't know if the cogged idler bearings really run any smoother with the cogged belts, but I'm happy with it. I also think the flanges on these bearings also cause less wear on the belts than the occasional rubbing on the printer guides with the stock ider bearings.

title: Vertical Sliding Door Posts for the Ultimaker 2/2+ and Extended

description.text:
Door posts for a vertical sliding door for the Ultimaker 2/2+ and Extended printers.

Fits on the left and right sides of the printer and accepts a 300mm wide 3mm acrylic sheet. (Cut the acrylic as high as you like).

Many places in the UK sell 3mm acrylic in 300mm wide sections so you may get away without needing to cut it, otherwise you can laser it or regular cutting techniques.

The gap is actually 4mm, acrylic isn't always perfectly 3mm and we know what 3D printers are like! 1/8" acrylic should fit (it's about 3mm). The OpenSCAD file can be adjusted fairly easily if you want to use a different thinckness.

The file UM2E-DoorBlank.svg can be used for laser cutting if you have access, it has rounded corners which help the door slide :-)

Be careful when the acrylic is fitted, clear acrylic looks just like an open door, particularly if you are use to just reaching into the ultimaker to get your part.

No latching mechanism is provided at this time. I use a bull dog clip to keep the door up when I need it. The model includes ridges between the acrylic and Ultimaker that could be used for a latching mechanism. If you design one please share :-)

White filament blends in well with the Ultimaker.

Photos of Cambridge Makespace Ultimakers and my own Extended 2+

Files

Prints in 4 parts. Lower and upper left and right segments.

File prefixes:

  • UM2- for the Ultimaker 2/2+
  • UM2E- for Ultimaker 2 Extended+

I don't have access to an Ultimaker 3 so I've not been able to try. Please comment if you get them to fit.

  • ....-All-3mm.stl files contains all 4 pieces.
  • ....-Lower-Both and -Upper-Both contain left and right for lower and upper
  • The the Lower-Left, Lower-Right etc. contain individual files.

So if one doesn't print properly, or breaks then you can select the appropriate part.

OpenSCAD file is also provided to allow further tweeking.

These files have a 2mm offset from the bottom of the printer. Use the OpenSCAD file if you want less or more.

End stops inside the bottom pieces prevent the door sliding all the way down so the SD card and controls are still accessible with the door closed. The ones in the photo have lower end stops. This can be adjusted in the OpenSCAD file if you wish.

Fitting

  • Carefully remove the two screws for the section you are installing on the printer (The Ultimaker supplied allan key works).
  • Be sure to pull the bolt as you remove it to bring the nut as close to the edge as you can, the sliders are JUST thin enough to get the bolt into the nut but not if it's fallen back in the hole.
  • Insert bolts, leave it a little loose until the second segment is attached on the side.
  • Don't over-tighten.
  • Once all four pieces are fitted slide in the acrylic sheet (from above).
  • Enjoy....

Printer settings

  • Large layer heights help
  • Brim defiantly helps as these are tall and thin and fall over easily.
  • Otherwise regular print settings in Cura should work.

Things To Note.

  • Don't just drop the acrylic, lower gently as when it hits the end stop it might break it off.
  • End stop keeps the door from going down past the SD card. I found that hitting the acrylic with my hand when forgetting it was there can cause the SD card to eject and stop a print!
  • Optionally fit a strip of draft excluder at the top of the opening.

Latest version will be available on Github: https://github.com/Tinamous/UltimakerDoor

Timelapse: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BP5jdTchPsw

author: KindjeKool

description.text:
This is a model of a Human Sacrum with 3.5mm holes representing an axis each; Vertical, Left oblique, and Right oblique. This was designed to help teach/learn diagnosing and treatment of somatic dysfunction with OMM/OTM. The holes were made that size so that you can push a 1/8" dowel rod through it to show the axis, as that is probably easier than printing such a small pole.

I will add pictures of the final print later when I get my camera.

In Osteopathic Medicine, OMM/OMT (or Osteopathic Manipulative Medicine/Treatment) is large part of the medical education. This area focuses on the body's individal components and their relationship to one another, and the body as a whole. The Sacrum is a bone that can often become rotated, or stuck, and is an important bone to understand well when treating with OMM. Because of the nature of the bone and the non-traditional axes around which it can rotate, the Sacrum can prove difficult for many students to visualize in a dysfunctional state. This model allows you to place dowel rods through it, so you can then physically rotate the Sacrum around those axes, and see exactly how it moves in relation to those axes.

Place a 1/8" dowel rod through the holes to see the 3 different axes.
The holes were modeled at 3.5mm in diameter, when I printed mine out a 1/8" dowel rod fit perfectly with a little bit of tension that holds it in place.
I bought a a small plastic drawer from Target and wanted to create inserts to help me organize all of my arduino components. Designed in Sketchup.

remixed_from.author: SpectreGadget
remixed_from.title: Audi S5 - Grocery Bag Hooks Mounting Inserts

description.text:
This is a remix of SpectreGadget's original mount/nut (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:703543) to accommodate different screws/bolts.

A modified VW/Audi part no. 811807577C.

Aftermarket boot/trunk grocery bag hook kits (eg. http://amzn.eu/625QZML) for Audi don't fit the A5/S5 coupe. The hooks I received came with M5 x 20mm hex socket cap head screws, which were too long for SpectreGadget's original mount. So this remix includes 3 different bolt/screw options using both the longer M5 and other common screws:

  • 4.6mm through hole suitable for M5 (5mm) screw
  • 3.0mm through hole suitable for 3.5mm (No. 6) self taping screws
  • 2.5mm through hole suitable for 3.0mm (No. 4) self taping screws

I performed testing on various hole sizes and print orientations for strength and durability in PLA. Printing upright causes a weakness in the "legs" which can cause them to snap when pressure was applied inwards. Laying the part flat lines up the layers along the leg allowing some additional flexibility. The part has been modified to lay flat so no support is needed.

No testing has been carried out in other materials.

title: Ridgid toolbox 1:10 scale
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Ridgid Toolbox battery compartment I designed for my 1:10 scale crawler. This was made to sit in the bed of my truck and be used as a battery compartment. It has a hole in the underside for wires to pass through. I also added holes for the 4 bolts I used to mount it to the bed. The magnets I used in the final construction are 6mm X 3mm. I believe the pull on them is in the 1.5lb range, more than enough to hold the lid on secure. The runners on the bottom are used to lift it off the bed slightly and can be left off if you wanted. The handles printed better as separate part, so they will need to be glued into place after cleanup.

I uploaded files for each individual component for smaller printers, and a single with everything on one plate for larger printers

Update My buddy wanted a skinny version of this to take up less bed space and have a more snug fit on a battery 35mm wide. So I put it on a diet! Uploaded single files for the slender version and another set file for printers with larger beds.

Let me know what ya think!

description.text:
Este proyecto está basado en el trabajo de T. Wirtl publicado en https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1090461 el 24 de octubre de 2015.
Nuestro proyecto consiste en sustituir el sensor que lleva (de un cigarrillo electrónico) que ya no se encuentran en el mercado y adaptarle un módulo KY-037 que es básicamente un micrófono con la posibilidad de ajustar la sensibilidad. Dejándonos hacer el clic del botón izquierdo con un soplido o una inspiración.

Funcionalidad
El usuario mueve el cursor usando una boquilla que básicamente funciona como un joystick. El botón derecho del mouse se maneja empujando la boquilla hacia la caja. El botón izquierdo del mouse es emulado por un sensor que reconoce si el usuario succiona aire a través de él.

Hardware software
Utilicé hardware y software de código abierto si es posible. El sistema está controlado por un Arduino Pro Micro. El Firmware fue escrito como un boceto de Arduino.

This project is based on the work of T. Wirtl published at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1090461 on October 24, 2015.
Our project consists of replacing the sensor that carries an electronic cigarette that is no longer in the market and costs a KY-037 module that is basically a microphone with the possibility of adjusting the sensitivity. Letting us click on the left button with a breath or an inspiration.

Functionality
The user moves the cursor using a mouthpiece that works like a joystick. The right mouse button is operated by pushing the nozzle towards the box. The left mouse button is emulated by a sensor that recognizes if the user sucks air through it.

Hardware software
Use open source hardware and software if possible. The system is controlled by an Arduino Pro Micro. The Firmware was written as an Arduino sketch.

description.text:
Grab Toy Infinite

Introduction:

A variation of the Grab Toy ++ (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2750749) where the number of expansion frames is a parameter; this way you can make the thing as large as you want.

I guess there is a limit of how large you can make it before hinge friction and mass of the thing prevents proper opening and closing but I have no idea what this limit may be. Also, depending on the material, a huge thing may snap under its own weight!

The PLA print in the photos is 6 frames long, which still kind of works although the grip at the jaw end is not very strong.

Please note that the STL file with the 10-frame GrabToy has only been included to show the OpenSCAD code can generate things as large as you want. I haven't printed it, so I cannot confirm it will function properly. In fact, having seen the 6-frames print I very much doubt the 10-frame version will be even able to fully close the jaws. In any case, if you do print it please tell us how it went!

Main routine:

GrabToyInfinite(N): generates a grab toy with N expansion frames. The corresponding number of hinges is 3*N+1.

Set global variable N to the desired value and press F6 to render. Keep in mind that more frames means longer time to render. Some indications: for N=10 it takes 12 minutes for my rusty i7-920 to render the thing at moderate quality and 42 minutes at high quality; for N=6 it takes 26 minutes at high quality).

Enjoy!

description.text: This is a little container for....whatever YOU decide to put in it. Interior diameter is 16mm. The cap and base have a gap of 0.1mm modeled between them. I chose this gap with the idea that I'd print the part with a 0.3mm layer height and probably get a snug "just right" fit because of the striations of the layers. Turns out, I was right. The cap fits snugly, and you can hear/feel the layers of the cap and base interlocking as it goes on. It won't come open in your pocket and you can pry it open using a fingernail or two.

description.text:
Enrich your plants with the powers of the force. 
A vase carved out of a yoda head. Nice for small plants, probably ideal to grow small herbs and spices.

1) Print
2) Fill with dirt
3) Plant seeds
4) Water often enough
5) Rejoyce with force-enhanced plantae Version from the pictures:
Printed at 130% in ABS (reprapworld), on an orca 0.3 with a reprap-fab hotend (0.5mm), geared extruder. Printed with support, but I'm not sure if it is needed. Hole carved in meshmixer. Really cool piece of software. Since the vase was a gift I decided to add stuff to the hole, just to demonstrate to the recipients how easy it is to do such cool details and that anything is possible. Ended up putting a small dude in there. Maybe wasn't the best choice, considering the meaning of 'there's someone buried in that vase'.

description.text:
Be aware that I adapted the inner diameter of the "hole" for the motion sensor to have it come out the proper size on my printer.

I recommend printing a few layers and then check if your sensor fits into the opening at the base of the holder. If not, simply adjust the size of the holder in your slicer and try again. But don´t be to generous with enlarging, it has to be a tight fit or the sensor will fall out.

For horizontal installation at the ceiling the sensor stays in place by gravity alone but if you use it vertically it might be a good idea to simply stuff some tissue paper behind it (doesn´t hurt for horizontal installation either) to keep it in place.

The plug is meant to cover the screw hole.
If you print the plug, be aware that you will need to shrink it, it probably won´t fit into the hole sized as it is. Never tried, if I do I will replace the STL with one of a fitting size.

title: Upside down condiment stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When condiments/chocolate syrup get low, they take forever to pour/squeeze out of the bottle. Of course, you could store them upside down, but they fall down every time you open the fridge door. You could buy the more expensive ones with the upside-down design, but you're not made of money.

You do have a 3D printer, though...

This was my solution to keeping my BBQ sauce, bleu cheese dressing, and chocolate syrup bottles upside down in the door of my fridge without them falling over all the time.

I may create a customizer out of this eventually, but for now I'll just upload it as it is.

Printer:

Tevo Tornado

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

You can use pretty much any infill you want, but remember that the holder needs to support the weight of a liquid-filled container in a cold environment. I like my usable parts to be heavier, so I used 25% and it came out flawlessly.

Preparation

I took all of my condiments out of the fridge and measured the neck of each one. They tended to fall into 3 categories:

  1. Custom bottles with fancy/odd tops or caps
  2. Super thin bottles (soysauce and such)
  3. Mid-sized neck diameter (seems to be some kind of standard across brands)

I chose #3 as my target since my chocolate syrup, BBQ sauce, and dressings all fell into this category.

Design

Made in OpenSCAD

  1. I made the hole diameter 2 millimeters larger than the fattest neck from category #3.
  2. I gave it a bottom without holes because I'd much rather wash it than the inside of my fridge if the supported bottle leaks.
  3. I gave it an elliptical base to match the most common cross-section of bottles. This way, other bottles crowding around it won't fall over.
  4. I beveled the top lip to make it look nicer.
  5. I included a small lip underneath to make removal from the bed, or sticky fridge shelf, easier.
For best stability in the door of the fridge, orient the holder so that the base's widest dimension is parallel to the arc of the fridge door.

title: X-End Carriages with clearance for Z couplers for Zaribo/Haribo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
OK, y'all, here's my hack for those of you using couplers on your Z motors. This is based on the previous Zaribo X-End (sorry, I got started before Wolfgang Schadow posted the new one), so you don't get his new gussets and top exit wiring. But what you do get is the ability to use a coupler (max size 20mm diameter, 25mm long) to connect your leadscrews. The pitch between the smooth rods and leadscrews is unchanged, so you still use the stock Zaribo Z motor holders and Z-top parts. There are three new parts you need to print: X-End-Motor, X-End-Idler, and a new X-carriage. The new X-carriage is built from Jon Madden's new one that moves the belt into perfect alignment (need to swap your rt side belt idler pulley to a 16T version). The only modification to the X carriage is the tab that hits the X-min limit switch, which I had to reposition do clear the coupler. Have fun!

STEP and STL files attached

comments.text: Thank you for these files! Now i can use other motors and leadscrews with my scratch built printer.
comments.author: devilhunter84

comments.text:
Thanks Devilhunter84, unfortunately those larger couplers will not fit with these parts. The 25mm diameter will not clear the parts as I designed them. I don’t have the CAD in front of me, so I cannot be certain, but if I remember correctly, the 25mm diameter would actually interfere with the lower x rod itself. Assuming you are building a “Prusa i3” style printer, as I assume you are since that what these parts are for, In order to use those couplings, you would need to lift the bed 10 or 12 mm so the top of the coupling was below the lower x rod, And then you could hack any needed extra diameter out of these parts below that rod. You’ll lose that amount of z build volume, of course, but you could make your frame taller to compensate. You would need longer z leadscrews if you wanted to do that.
Or if your printer frame allows, you could just drop your z motors the 10-12mm, but then again you would lose the z build volume.

print_settings.Notes:: Print this object on edge to create strong fastener tabs.

title: LED Headlights for Monoprice Select Mini

description.text:
These LED headlights are only for the Monoprice Select Mini. I’ve seen other LED lighting but I wanted lighting specifically for the tip. In the past I used a flashlight to really see what was going on there. I also thought blue LEDs might look cool (see action photos).

Details:

The project takes typical DIY skills and these parts, tools, and materials:

Parts: Headlight object, 2 LEDs (blue, wide angle), 1 resistor (270 Ohms), about 32” of +/- wire (fine gauge), 2 small screws.

Materials: Heat-shrink tubing, 1 small wire tie, solder

Tools: Soldering iron, a stick or snake, tape, drill and bits, screwdriver, needle, pliers, a lighter

How to assemble:
Print the headlight mount on edge to produce strong fastener tabs. Disconnect the power cable from the Mini. Position the mount as show. Install temporarily using a drill and 1 screw at the outboard side. Drill a hole at the top edge of the mounting tab for the +/- wire pair. Create the inboard screw hole using a hot needle (or small nail) held in a pair pliers. To avoid welding, first make a shallow mark then remove the mount before melting the through hole big enough for your screw.

Place the Mini, back down, on your work surface (support the column). Remove the bottom plate and tilt it out of the way (right). Tape the +/- pair of wires to a stick or stout wire and snake them through the Mini column as show. Solder the + wire to the switch + out, and the – wire to a nearby – wire. Add heat-shrink.

Unwrap the feed-tube cover, route the +/- wires along with it.
Run the +/- wire through the wire hole. Give yourself a few inches extra wire to work with. It can later be tucked away in the base by pulling from there.

Press fit (or glue) the 2 LEDs into the mount and solder as shown. Solder the resistor and wires while adding heat-shrink then secure all using one small zip tie as shown. *There are two small holes between the LEDs for optional securing methods.

Install the completed headlight assembly. Pull any excess wire into the Mini base and reinstall the baseplate and the feed tube wrap.

Done.

*This method turns the headlights on when the Mini is switched on. I did not want to tap into the fan or heater. The LEDs are angled towards the hot end but not focused directly on it. I recommend using wide angle LEDs for good flood lighting.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Good

100%

Notes:

A heat resistant filament is recommended. However, I tested PLA for 30 minutes at maximum heat with no damaging effects.

0.2

Infill:

20

Wet Vac attachments. This Thing is a Work-In-Progress !

I tried my pieces and am very UN happy with results with the amount of suction. Ok 3/4" ID w/ straight exit tube had a lack of suction and the 5/8ID tube at an angle with the output necked down actually had positive air flow, not negative ! OPPS ! They fit nicely. I am revising, reprinting and will test again this weekend. I will post new files after I test them this time. Sorry.

The story behind these parts.
I had a large tractor tire go flat, come off the rim and gather water. Before I reseated it I wanted the water out of the tire. I could not fit my hand inside or get a Wet Vac hose inside. I looked around the barn for something and found a HVLP paint gun and sandblasting gun for inspiration. Having a large volume suction spray gun adds other possible uses than just starting a syphon. I have several Wet Vacs and even a couple high volume – low pressure fans just waiting for the next use. So I grabbed a small diameter tube and modeled it, but only 3” long. Dimensions are rounded in JPGs. My parts have fit properly as printed, pretty happy with that!
So I made Wet Vac-1.5 to 1.18 od connector pipe.stl
From that model I created the part with a suction hose connector. I figured ¾” ID tubing would be easy to find. I have printed this one and had good air flow blowing past the hole creating a nice vacuum.
So I made Wet Vac-75 id suction tube straight.stl
Then I thought funneling it would increase pressure and suction.
So I made Wet Vac-75 id suction tube w neckdn.stl
I liked the neckdown and thought it might be handy to have a blower attachment.
So I made Wet Vac-1.5 to .44 neckdown.stl
Then I went to the store to get tubing. I was in luck they had a whole selection of tubing clearance. Would you believe not one inch of ¾” ID ! They did have a have a roll of 5/8” ID x ¾” OD tubing.
So I made Wet Vac 625 id suction tube w neckdn.stl
Then just to see if even more output diameter reduction increased suction I modeled Wet Vac 625 id suc tube w half output.stl
And yes, it did occur to me that most people will have a Wet Vac and not a blower. At least one of my Wet Vacs does not have a way to attach to output. So I took the design to the logical beginning point and made a connector for the 5/8” ID tubing to the hose so you can just attach it to Wet Vac and suck it into Wet Vac.
So I made Wet Vac 625 id suction tube STRAIGHT.stl
Also included is the Autocad 2010 file.
More to come. I will probably create an adaptor for the standard large to small tubes. I am also think of making a couple hose attachments for some special purpose ideas.

author: zerandir

description.text:
I created these 3/4" high labels to identify which drawers hold which tools. By applying magnetic tape to the back, you can stick them to metal toolbox drawers and easily move them around when you change the layout of your toolbox.

The STL files and the Customizer will create monochrome labels. You have to pause your printer and change spools to make the lettering a different color than the background. I recommend pausing after the first text layer before changing spools.

I used this magnetic tape from Home Depot: https://www.homedepot.com/p/MASTER-MAGNETICS-3-4-in-x-26-ft-Magnetic-Tape-with-Dispenser-96774/204752648

Sometimes it doesn't stick very well. In those cases I just apply a little bit of super glue.

I've supplied a few ready to print labels. If you need other ones you can run the Customizer. A few things to note: lower case letters with descenders will go off the bottom of the default size label. Also you will have to adjust the length of the label for your text.

I've also added the ability for different fonts, text sizes, or changing different label height. I am not checking for a valid font, so if you change font, be sure you know what you are doing.

description.text:
After waking up to some pancakes (see picture), I traced back the issue to the model. I've repaired the parts so that they can print properly now without making any more surprise pancakes.

Fixes:

  • Fixed normals
  • Closed solids
  • Removed Self Intersections
  • Made manifold

Some of the models required multiple passes to be completely free of errors. Rechecked in Windows 3D Builder just to be sure.

Update Log:
2018-01-25: It seems the base pins disappeared when fixing the mesh. The pins are added separately.

title: Bracket to mount solenoid for Virtual pinball machine force feedback.

description.text:
This is a mount for a solenoid to be used in a Virtual Pinball machine to provide force feedback. The solenoid impacts the bracket to make the noise/feedback. This is for a solenoid that I purchased from amazon the description for that solenoid is

Uxcell a13120200ux0916 Push Pull Open Frame Solenoid

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HR8H38A/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The coil mounts to the bracket with M3x6mm long screws and then the entire assembly attaches to the cabinet with wood screws. Be sure to use the correct length M3 screws otherwise they will damage the winding on the coil.

I would use some loctite on the screws that mount the solenoid to the bracket and also on the little acorn nut on the solenoid so it doesn't come loose during use.

title: Overhang Torture Test - Pillar from Hell

description.text:
Did you ever wondered what a 3D Printer's nightmare looks like? Well, here you are the Pillar from Hell, a [relatively] quick overhang torture test.

I noticed that the standard "flat" overhang used in many test can be a little forgiving in some case, so I used a rounded edge and tiny spikes that should be harder for the printer as an overhang.

Why it's octagonal? Well, the cooling system can affects how well an overhang is printed so, doing it octagonal allows to check a lot of orientation with a single model.

Furthermore, I noticed that some overhang test can wiggle a bit during print due to the big, unsupported, curve they create. Due to the fact that each "step" of this test is indipendent, every overhang is tested alone.

To make it easy to compare 2 Pillar from Hell, I've added a little arrow on the base. By default, it should print "away from you", but you can rotate in any way you like it.

Sadly, There is no space to write the angle. For reference, the pillar start with a 40 degree angle (easy enough for every printer) and ends at 85 degree (almost impossibile), in 5 degrees steps.

In case you don't want to print the entire pillar, you can sink it down in your slicer, or stop the print at a precise height. For reference:

The base is 6 mm tall
Every "step" is 5 mm tall
The tip is 6 mm tall and starts at 56 mm

The entire pillars weight 9 g [or less] and takes from 1h to 2h to print. I tried to save as much plastic and time as possibile. You can find 3 STL, based on your layer width. I've optimized the pillar for 0.40, 0.45 and 0.48 mm layer width (the 3 most used for a 0.4 nozzle). If you use other layer width, just let me know in the comment section!

Finally, even if your printer will fail some test, the final model actually still looks cool!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

The ones you want to test

Infill:

5%

Notes:

Remember: print speed can affect your outcome!

author: Mystikal

description.text:
You can find a full writeup at instructables

This is a lockable machinist's toolbox I built last year. It is constructed entirely from 1/4 inch baltic birch. The hardware was purchased from Rockler. The exterior was finished with 4 coats of polyurethane varnish while the inside was left unfinished. I lined the inside with laser cut foam to cushion the tools. The toolbox has worked very well so far, surviving regular trips between my apartment and our makerspace. You can find a quick video showing how the front panel works here https://youtu.be/wgjU_0VMBQE

The drawers lock into the frame so that you cannot accidentally pull them out and spill your tools. The drawer locking mechanisms are just screwed onto the back of each drawer and then rotated into place. You can see an example in the attached video. https://youtu.be/HAA-dLD_6Is
150W laser cutter, 80% power at 10mm/s
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/wgjU_0VMBQE" ></iframe>

comments.text:
Hey!
Cool toolbox!
comments.author: NicApicella

comments.text:
Hi,
I added a video showing how the front panel works.
I have carried it by the handle on the top, since it has a pretty even weight distribution. Though, I would make sure to get a sturdy handle for the top since the toolbox gets rather heavy quickly when you add your tools. As I add more tools, I have switched to using the side handles more. It tends to be easier for me when lugging around that much weight.
There are currently 4 clasps. If the 2 on the sides are eliminated the weight will be held by the two front clasps and the hinge. This all just depends on what you want to put in the box. If you are just putting light stuff in there, 2 clasps would be fine. If you are loading it down with steel tools, 4 clasps would likely be better.
comments.author: NicApicella

comments.text: Thank you so much for the video! It clears up a lot—and it's just like I expected. :-)
comments.author: DrJekyll2k

comments.text: I think you are right that there is a possibility for the front panel to lift up if you just had clasps on the front.  I actually tested this a bit and found that the lower lip keeps the panel from pushing forward and up when you pull on the lid.  Also, the knobs are recessed into the panel, keeping it from sliding up.  I only tested this with about 10lbs so more weight could cause a failure.  Thanks for pointing this out, it does look like having the side latches are needed.  Especially when everything is weighed down.

title: EmuPi RetroPie Mini Arcade Cabinet v1

description.text:
No 3d printer? Buy the printed shell from my etsy shop:
https://www.etsy.com/listing/588892589/emupi-retropie-mini-arcade-cabinet-v1-3d?ref=listing-shop-header-0

This is a project I started on a few weeks ago and I am very happy with the results. I decided to share it with the community for those that would like to make there own version.

For the print settings you will need supports mostly just for the parts that connect the shell pieces together since they print in the air. As far as infill I had tried with 20 percent but it was to thin so the final version was printed with 100 percent I do think you could get away with less than that but I did it to be certain. This will print on a standard 200x200x200 printer I made sure to model it that way so that many people could use and print it.

Parts used for the build:
Raspberry Pi 3:
http://amzn.to/2DIXkTc
7" LCD Screen:
https://goo.gl/75PsiF
Arcade button and joystick kit:
https://goo.gl/1YAxg8
Speaker bonnet kit: (requires soldering) I may offer an install service
http://amzn.to/2Fafbje
Speakers used:
http://amzn.to/2rCheuu
Double sided adhesive (for speaker mounting & lcd screen):
http://amzn.to/2F7EW3F
Velcrow:(used to mount pi board in case I wanted to remove it)
http://amzn.to/2DFBqQL
You will also need some m3 screws I suggest x 12 and x 20 along with an even longer set of 4 for securing the button and joystick face to the bottom

Assembly should be pretty explanatory just secure the parts to each other using the m3 screws I did not need any nuts the plastic was extremely solid and connected to each other without the need. If the m3 screws wont grip into the holes use a screwdriver to twist back and forth with some pressure on the holes which will allow the screws to grip.

As far as setting up retropie just refer to:
https://retropie.org.uk/docs/First-Installation/

Good luck! If you have any questions let me know I will do my best to help!

description.text:
This is an adapter for a pinlock quick disconnect (QD) for a 5 gallon pinlock keg to a 1/2" barb fitting. This adapter will allow you to connect a pinlock QD to a submersible pump to aid in beer line cleaning. Due to the twisting nature when locking these QDs, I added an oblong portion to help you turn the adapter onto the QD.

Once you print, all you need to do is add an o-ring and you're all set to use it!

The idea for this came from NeoPlane's Ball Lock keg adapter, then the 1-piece printing idea came from ArnieX's remix. Thanks for the ideas, guys!

Notes:

Make sure to lay the parts flat on the bed
Printed with ABS

Material

You will need

  • 1 M2 x 20 screw and 2 M2 nuts
  • 2 M3 x 20 screws and 2 M3 nuts

The M2 screw will be the hinge and the M3 screws will close the mount on the handlebar.

I did this mount from scratch, although many are available here, for a few reasons:
1) some of the models available were difficult to print
2) some were very brittle
3) some would not position the GPS exactly where I wanted (the center of the handlebar, at a distance easy to read)

My initial designs were also flawed, because I was printing only two parts, leading to a printing orientation which would always leave part of it very fragile. In fact, the first two versions broke in the first rides.
This version is printed in 3 different pieces, each one oriented in a manner that the layers will be oriented perpendicular to the effort the mount will support, making it stronger. It's also much easier to print and allows for a nicer finish.

remixed_from.title: Analog parking brake for driving simulations

remixed_from.author: mike_mattala
remixed_from.title: NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory

description.text:
Analogue parking brake

A remix of Analog parking brake for driving simulations by HaraDaya - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2286976

I liked his design, but I wanted it to be fully 3D printable (no bits of old coat-hangers or PVC pipe) and I wanted to get rid of the rubber band on the pawl, as I felt this would be very easy to achieve its job simply by putting a spring between the handbrake button (pushbutton.stl) and the handbrake lever (lever_mk3_reinforced_rubberband_hook.stl), inside the handle tube.

I could probably have deleted the hook on the side of the lever too, but I'd already printed it at that point.

So I made a really simple tube for the handle which combines with the existing parts. If I were to do it again, I'd make handle_end_piece.stl, PVC_adapter.stl and Handle_tube.stl into a single piece, and make it more realistic/ergonomic. But for now, this'll do.

HaraDaya used a bit of pipe because he was worried about strength - but printed with PLA, the handle seems as strong as the proverbial oxen. Don't know if the 3D printed nut and bolt will hold up over the long term, but I couldn't be bothered to wait for a bolt to come from an ebay seller, so I just made this. If it turns out to be too weak, I'll either redesign for a 7mm bolt instead of a 6mm, or just use a metal one. My handbrake will be used in driving simulations, not manic racing games, so it shouldn't get much abuse. The pushrod seems strong enough too.

If the tolerances are too tight, you might need to use some sandpaper to sand down bits that push together. I like a tight interference fit, with a touch of epoxy, to keep things strong.

When my arduino turns up, I'll know more about the durability.

I may update soon with some kind of cover.

BOM

2x M3 10mm screws (one can be longer if desired)
A rubber band (optional - I don't bother)
WH148 ≤10k potentiometer
Positive and negative leads
Arduino
Micro USB cable
Some epoxy

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

comments.author: pdien

comments.text: Your printer is just set up with different tolerances to mine. It's normal - just resize the nut slightly - do a search for "nut job" on thingyverse and you can easily make a nut to the exact specs you require, or just make the nut 1 percent smaller in your slicer and reprint it.
comments.author: pdien

comments.text: Okay, I see. I was going to resize it, but I noticed the outside dimensions on the nut and bolt head are identical (checked with calipers). It's just the hole was too big. I'll try resizing it. Thanks.

comments.text: How well did the 3D printed spring work? I was thinking of making one for a future design, and I'm curious if it actually works.
comments.author: BlueChromis

comments.text: So far, flawlessly.  I printed out a few different sizes, then eventually added the washers to it.  It's all of 2 days old, so I can't talk about longevity, but so far it's working a treat.

comments.text: Cool. I think it'll hold just fine, I over-estimated how much abuse it would need to handle. It's actually the rubberbands that get chewed up after some weeks, so if your spring works that would be great. Where does the spring go? And what material do you use for it?
comments.author: HaraDaya

comments.text: Yeah, I have had no end of problems with the rubber bands, such as not being short enough, but being too short if doubled up.  Rather than trying to explain where the spring goes, I uploaded a bad jpg - no photoshop on this PC, that's the best I could do with mspaint (yuk!) - but you should get the idea.
comments.author: HaraDaya

comments.text: Oooh, for some reason I thought the spring was somehow for the lever itself, not the button. That's a way better solution yeah. Never imagined you could print a working spring.
comments.author: MudBarf

comments.text: They may well break, I really need time to tell you if making a spring is a good idea or not! So far though, it's working exactly the way I hoped it would.
comments.author: HaraDaya

comments.text: I'm gonna keep mine using rubberbands for the simplicity of it, easy to source, but I definitely want to find a solution for them breaking so often. I already know a few reasons why they wear out so fast.
comments.author: MudBarf

comments.text: Yeah, the different spring mechanisms I've looked at so far are all coming up short for the main lever spring.  One thing you might want to consider (I'm thinking of trying this) is to replace the hooks with some kind of screw down retention mechanism, so you can use a single piece of rubber - for example, a long thin piece cut out of an old inner tube.  That way anything stretchy can be cut to size.  A piece of elastic from your old smalls.  Your wife's scrunchy.  Whatever is stretchy and comes to hand.

New 2017-10-10 Added applications exported from Processing 3 for all major operation systems. Included a .gpx file to the .zip file so that you can test it out directly. Place your own GPX file in the same folder as the application, important that you name your file 'input.gpx' . Staret the program and the 3d-model will appear on screen. Press 's' to export the model, the output .stl will be named 'path.stl' and will be saved alongside your input file. End of New Who doesn't want a physical representation of the perfect run, the longest run, or that crappy run that even really wasn't something to remember even afterwards? I know that I did, but I couldn't find any way when searching the net for a solution. Alas, I set out to make my own program that could turn my .GPX files to .STLs that could be printed out. I found appropriate libraries for Processing, and managed to work out a way to parse the files and translate the data to points in a voxel array.

You will need: Processing -download from www.processing.org
GPS data library for Processing -for parsing .GPX files, download and install
*toxic libraries for Processing -download and install You will also need: Some sort of GPS device that can log your activities as GPX files. Usually people use GPS watches, iPhones and such, combined with some sort of service like Garmin Connect, Runkeeper or Strava. My program comes in two flavors: one for creating meshes that shows the path floating in space (GPS_xy_floating.pde), and one that shows the elevation stretched, originating from a base level (GPS_xy_solid.pde).

  • Get out and run, why not a scenic one?

  • Download your file for local storage on your computer, place it in the same folder as your .pde.

  • Edit the .pde with your .GPX file name.

  • Run the sketch, your run will now be parsed and visualized on your screen. Don't mind that it will look mirrored.

  • Press the 's'-key. This will save the mesh as 'path.stl' in your sketch folder. It will overwrite any 'path.stl' file without asking, so rename your output if you don't want it accidentally destroyed after it's been exported.

  • Load your mesh in favorite slicer and print. If you create a floating track, don't forget to print it with support.
    • I have only personal .GPX files from the northern hemisphere, so I can't confirm that this will work for everyone. If you want to contribute, please feel free to make a suggestion or your own remix. As for now, these versions suite my current needs.

comments.text:
When testing at home, 1 seems to be the lowest possible setting for the BoxBrush size. What you can do is to expand the volume that the brush is painting in ( requires more memory ). As it is now, the gps track is drawn within a cube of 100x100x100 (100 in the z space isn't required really) voxels (a volumetric array). See what happens if you expand it to 200x200x60 or so. Make sure to alter the code in the pixelToGeo()-function so that the mesh fills out the volumetric array.
This would get you a better resolution combined with the smaller brush size.

comments.text: If you download the .pde, open it in Processing and save it, Processing will create a folder on your drive where it will be stored. On my Mac the path is something like 'Documents\Processing\GPS_xy_solid\GPS_xy_solid.pde'. Place your .gpx file in the same folder as GPS_xy_solid.pde, and change the file name in GPS_xy_solid.pde so that it matches the name of your own .gpx file. Voila!

author: andrewkingme

title: Crazy 3d printed thing Kisslicer slicable - manual support

description.text:
Kisslicer left gaps in the hook parts, so when pressure was placed on them, they broke away from the rest of the part.  
If you look close at the hooks on the original file, the triangles don't terminate with the structure, which is why kisslicer sees it as separate parts. Modified in solidworks, so that the hooks are part of the rest of the structure.   
Also put in breakaway support for the horizontal hook gaps, and a brim, as the original file broke away from the printbed half-way through. (printing on PVA on glass, so not the best adhesion method, i know.)

Still requires support for the arms, might at some point put in breakaway support for these as well.  
UPDATE: Uploaded 'full support' model', no generated support needed. Uploaded an assembly pic as well.

title: Turny: an alternative bluetooth video game controller

description.text:
3D printed case parts for an alternative bluetooth video game controller called "Turny", designed for use in a game jam. The controller uses four potentiometer knobs and one button and streams data over bluetooth (using an Arduino-programmed, low-energy bluetooth module) to a custom-designed video game running on a desktop/laptop computer. The case also features a front-facing three-colour led for feedback to the player, a usb port for re-programming and charging, and an on/off slide switch.

For more details on the project, see:

remixed_from.title: LulzBot Mini bed USB camera mount

title: LulzBot Mini bed USB camera mount, v2.1 Lulzbot extruder toolhead

description.text:
Remixed from "LulzBot Mini bed USB camera mount" by sabi to support the V2.1 extruder toolhead from Lulzbot.

The V2.1 extruder has another fan on it near the hot end that juts out in the Y-dimension and overhangs out of the bed where the the original one did not.

I basically used the .scad file from sabi's thing to get the mount parts individually into .STL and then used OpenSCAD again to extend the connector to the webcam mount.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.200 mm layer height

Infill:

10%-20%

Notes:

Printed on standard settings in ABS (200 micron layer height, 10% infill)

Refer to original Remixed from "LulzBot Mini bed USB camera mount" by sabi

Contains info on USB webcam and hardware for attaching webcam.

Used OpenSCAD to export each mount individually into their own STLs (using camera_mount_floating_ends.scad).

The assembly including adding a longer connector, is done in camera_mount_v2p1.scad using adjusted code from the remix origin .scad file.

There were some problems rendering in OpenSCAD the webcam mount .STL, as it kept generating an internal assertion error, and then dropping the webcam mount portion.

I used some mesh functions in Fusion 360 to convert webcam mount STL mesh to a B-rep, and then exported back into an .STL from Fusion 360. Later, I discovered this was causing non-manifold models, so I re-meshed the STL mesh model in Fusion 360 to make the mesh manifold.

Then in meshmixer, I edited webcam mount model to reduce the poly count.

These were finally able to successfully render in OpenSCAD so I was able to generate the full STLs for printing.
Github: https://github.com/idcrook/psychic-winner/tree/master/LulzBot_Mini_bed_USB_camera_mount_v2p1_toolhead

author: dpc

title: SLS - Orion, Service Module, ICPS - Version 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Visit: NASA Models to get printed models in kit form.

Update 2/19/2018

I have updated the ICPS-ThrusterLOXSupportCage with a 3 part version ICPS-V2-ThrusterLOXSupportCage based on feedback from someone who works on the SLS program.

The engine was also modified to be closer to what is represented in the actual pictures, not the artist renditions.

Update 2/15/2018

I finished the build of the model using colored filament. The one on the left is the finished version, the one on the right was glued together right off the printer (raw print).

In my opinion, it looks pretty good. I would probably hit the Silver parts with a bright silver spray paint if you want it to pop. Also, I hit the gold ball tank in the Sm with gold paint (not in picture). You can see layering on the Avionics rings when you glue it together. So some sanding there is required.

Also, I have been working with Falk Smilowski who seems to be doing a great job. He is producing the model with the Education Stand. No doubt because he is a Physics and Engineering student. Follow his Make if you want to learn any tricks from a person other then me on the build process. I'm sure he will be updating it as regularly as he can.

Update 2/10/2018

Added the detailed interior of the Service Module. It is located at SLS - Service Module Interior.

I decided to break out some additional parts into their own Thing to not clutter up this complete 1/56 scale model.

Update 2/07/2018

For those interested in purchasing this model, rather than printing your own. I will be updating the model kits with the colored filament parts as soon as I find a silver I like. It also comes in a fully assembled and finished form.

A few things since the last update:

I am uploading the parts for the Service Module now. Which means all the parts should be there except for the stand.

I have a good sample of what this model looks like printed using colored filament for the various pieces. I have not glued all the pieces together yet, because I am waiting on the orange and silver filament to be delivered. I have some silver filament, buy they did not seem any better than grey. I also had to do some redesign on the Solar Array Wings to break out the blue parts.

And finally, I went to watch the launch of the SpaceX Falcon Heavy launch yesterday. That was fun!

Update 2/01/2018

As promised, I uploaded all of the ICPS to correspond to the assembly doc. It was a busy day for me, so maybe over the weekend I will start uploading the Service Module or stand.

Additionally, I started a new print. This time I am doing it using the corresponding colors of the parts. So that when it is printed, hopefully, I will just need to assemble it.

Tomorrow, I hope to make contact with someone at NASA to possibly get better measurements for this as well as the next project which is the Curiosity Rover and its upgrades for the Mars 2020 rover. I live about 45 minutes from Kennedy so this should be an easy thing. I'm also looking forward to the launch of the Delta heavy on Tuesday.

I also have to ask again, if someone out there has some contacts for me/this work, please contact me directly.

Update 1/31/2018

Both scale models are now built. They are displayed next to each other so you can figure out which size best suits you. There are a pair of eyeglasses between them to allow a better feel.

I had to redesign the stand grip. It was moved more forward to balance the weight, it is also more aesthetically pleasing.

I will begin loading more parts tomorrow, now that I know they all fit together.

Update 1/29/2018

Getting close. I have more assembly pictures from an actual assembly.

Update 1/28/2018

I have all the parts for the 1/75th scale version primed and painted as well as an action stand (not shown). Here is how it is looking.

The parts are grouped according to color, not build relationship. The coloring scheme is my own. Obviously, you may choose different colors. For example, Various renditions of the capsule are black, white or "metallic".

Update 1/27/2018

So I decided to spend the day building the model from a new print of the final parts. This is the first time I have done that. All previous models were build, tweak, paint and put in place. So a model has never been built from start to finish. I am doing this to make sure all the pieces are present and fit properly and for "assembly" instructions.

Update 1/26/2018

ChiefGlider noticed that several of the parts for the Orion Capsule were 5X larger then they should be. I am updating the STLs now.

Update 1/25/2018

I have added the parts for the Orion Crew Module and provided the first pass at the assembly instructions. You will find the PDF instructions in the files section.

It is recommended that you print the Forward Compartment pieces using a .2 mm nozzle at .10 or .15 layer height.

Some of the remaining details:

1) Finish the Assembly Documentation
2) Rename some of the parts to be more accurate
3) Resize and Reorient the parts (some need to be flipped because supports are not required)

The current scale of the models that I am working with are approximately 1/56 and 1/75. I will be publishing the 1/56 scale.

If there are any last minute suggestions, please let me know as soon as possible. I am anxious to move onto the Curiosity Rover and its Mars 2020 upgrades.

Since I am reasonably new to Thingiverse, if there is a proper way to handle a "version 2" of something, let me know. Should I create a new thing (like I am doing now) or update the previous version in some way?

Also, should I treat this as one big model with (n) parts or should I break out each module into a separate thing Orion, Service Module, ICPS, stands, etc?

Any constructive input is appreciated.

Regards,
-H

title: Bathgate Prototype mag stand for 8mm magnet

description.text:
this is a prototype mag stand to hold a piece of sculpture or any other small magnetic object.

The column up the middle is just support material. it should snap at the thin seem revealing the cavity that will receive a 8mmx3mm disk magnet. Edit: I have also added a version with the support structure removed for those who require this.

Disclaimer: The opening for the magnet is very slightly oversized, but depending on your printer, this opening may be too large or too small. The 8mm magnets I have found are not great on tolerance either so some variability here is going to come into play.

I had to open up the hole in my stand slightly with a drill bit, sand paper would have worked as well. You may find you have the opposite issue of the magnet being too loose. A little glue can be of help in that situation.

My point is, I have done my best to make this a good size but some fiddling may be required due to things outside of my control.

Your Pal
CB

description.text:
A simple, lightweight bookend.

Design goals:

  • Low filament usage
  • Subtle, unobtrusive style
  • Easy to insert and remove
  • Should hold up a row of small paperbacks
  • The part that slides under books should be as thin as possible to avoid book damage

The STL file with the _brim suffix has a small, easily removable brim built in to secure the most wiggly part of the print.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print this lying on its side (which should be the default orientation in the STL file).

The model is tuned for a 0.4mm nozzle. Configure your slicer for at least two outside walls for best results (it should end up slicing as almost all walls, except for a small bit of infill in the middle).

A brim of some kind is recommended. If you have a particularly sticky bed (like PEI) you can try the STL file that has a small brim included on the end - this worked for my setup without using the slicer's brims.

Designed from scratch in DesignSpark Mechanical.

Inspired by the form factor of Simple Bookend.

description.text:
This is a kind-of-but-not-exact Yakima Kayak/Canoe saddle. The box comes with 4, but last summer I got home with one missing. I couldn't find a way to get just one, so thought I'd make up something that will work in its place.

The STL's are a little wonky because I originally modeled it very much like the actual saddle, which has (at least) 4 separate parts, where the clamping mechanism is attached to the bottom of the saddle.

I printed the first design and connected the parts together with epoxy. Afterwards, I found some strength flaws and a few other measurement errors. When I made those changes, I just connected the mesh of the base to the top to make one solid piece. It is much stronger that way and no worries about the glued pieces coming apart.

I'm sure anyone wanting this can make the needed repairs. My slicer (IdeaMaker) repaired my Saddle STL as it wasn't perfect.

For this design, I used a 140mm M6 screw and nut (you really need 170mm), The nut slides into a slot in the bottom of the clamp part (Use the ThingiView to see it). The rest is easy to figure out. I might also add an M6 washer between the knob and saddle housing.

I also modeled a small hole into the saddle itself from what I might make into a locker, but not sure of that yet. The knob has an extra hole for what I imagine might me for a locking screw, but I didn't model a matching screw hole in the saddle, and no locking screws came with the original.

On my print, the holes came out just enough too small that I initially had to screw the M6 all the way through it and then work it back and forth a few times until I could "saw" loose enough interior plastic to allow it to slide through. That wasn't too difficult and you might not have that problem.

You might decide to use a different screw size, but if you change the size of the holes, make sure you do so in all three pieces and consider the nut slot in the clamp.

I haven't mounted my kayak to it yet, will let you know how it goes. I printed the one shown with PLA and the play in the saddle is rugged and nice. ABS would be better. Of course, how well it will take bouncing down the road, I don't know yet.

Printer:

TEVO Tornado

Supports:

Scale the knob to 19.2mm x 58.5mm x 25mm. I printed it on its back with no supports (Refer to screenshot in my slicer).

Scale the clamp to 29.5mm x 50mm x 53.5mm. I printed it as shown in the print orientation screenshot. I don't really think I needed supports here, but just in case, I used them. I also printed this one on a raft to give it a bit more stability as the printer worked out the top layers.

Scale the saddle to 170mm x 94.8mm to 141.7mm. I printed this on its side (see the picture of the print orientation). I used supports (in yellow) just in case. This took my printer 2 days to print.

description.text:
Since i only found laser cut versions of this kind of clock, i decided to give it a shot and design my own version of it. It features a black background in the top portion, since i really liked my numbers to be white, but they became kind of invisible on the wall. If you dont want this, simply print the clock without the wall bracket and mount the clockwork directly to the wall.

The clock has kind of a large footprint and is designed to be printed on a CR-10 or printers similar in size.

Everything can be put together without glue, except for the clockwork, which has to be glued into the wall bracket.

The design uses a standard clockwork which i borrowed of an old wall clock and should work with most clockworks available, even though you might need to adjust the wall bracket as well as the hole in the small gear. I also removed one gear inside so the shaft that sets the hours spins freely. This helps to hold the small gear in place and to give it more stability.

Here is a small time lapse video showing the clock in action: https://youtu.be/pgFnwKWl_P0

Layer hight: 0.2

Infill: 15 Percent

Support: Off (Except for the wall bracket)

Turns out there was already another version of this clock on thingiverse that i couldn´t find for some reason when i designed mine. It uses a different design approach, but since technically it is the original design, it´s just fair to link it here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12173

comments.text: Where do I get the clock mechanism?
comments.author: ChuckAckerman

comments.text: You can get clockworks from pretty much every standard wall mounted clock. I got mine from some old ikea clock that i found in the trash. If you dont have an old clock lying around, you can buy some cheap clock on ebay/craigslist or even on flea markets. You can also get new clockworks from maker shops on ebay, but they are a lot more expensive.

title: Aluminatus Cable Wire Drag Chain Parts & X End Stop

description.text:
These are parts needed to add cable chains to the TrinityOne Aluminatus.

The Aluminatus Chain Mount & X End Stop are used to give you something to attach the cable chain too and actually have two fasteners so it cannot twist. It also gives you a more solid X-End Stop with a large footprint. It comes out farther to actually cover the entire hoop of the micro switch. The original on mine would just partially catch it. There are also two vertical tabs for each side so this part cannot rotate.

One 5mm button head bolt goes through the Cable Chain end and the Chain Mount & X End Stop into the X carriage. The other hole requires a 3mm nut to be inserted. This will be trapped under the Chain Mount & X End Stop so it is unseen when assembled and no wrench is needed to hold it. A 3mm button head bolt is used in the other hole of the cable chain end.

The wires will come around the cable chain end and be fastened with a 2.5mm wide zip ties. The wires will route down and around the extruder motor.

These ends are designed to work with these cable chain links:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:611593
It should also work with the version that is not open:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11978

The Aluminatus Cable Chain End X to Z has been added. This transitions the wiring from from X to Z. It has two holes to mount it to the X Carriage existing holes with allen socket head 3mm bolts. It also has some holes that I added to use a separate mount between it and the motor. This bracket was going to zip tie to the motor, but I found that it was rigid enough without this, so I did not make one. There are holes to zip tie the wires down and there are two round cutouts on the part that goes up for a zip tie, but I did not put one on there. The X motor and X limit wires can come up through the bottom hole and join the Extruder wiring to continue on.

The Aluminatus Open Chain End Z mounts to the upright using two T slot nuts and 5mm button heads. There are two holes to secure the wires with a zip tie.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5PSEejv7VGA&feature=youtu.be

title: Legs for Large glue stick stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
if you have the glue dispenser already glued then only print the "gluestick stand back.stl"
the file "gluestick stand front.stl" is meant for those who don't have the dispenser assembled yet and want to reduce their use of glue.

you will still need to glue or melt (soften and mash together) the side holder

to make this thing you will also need https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2740787

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

should work well with 10-15% infill. but i printed with my recent setting of 20%

no supports is important because it will be hard to get supports out of the hole post printing
no raft or brim needed.

my prefered slicer is matter control

if the holes have any danglies remove the danglies.
you will need the following hardware
4 m3 nuts
4 m3 countersunk screws at least 12 mm in length (countersunk screws have the whole screw measured, including the head)

if you glued or melted the 2 halves together then you don't need "glue stick stand front.stl" and can reduce the needed screws and nuts down to 2 each.

i imported the 2 halves of the dispenser into tinkercad, align them and joined them.
then i rotated it to get the angle, and then i modelec my item using 4 objects
(square, cylinder (hole), polygon (hole), square (hole), half circle (hole))

using the original model i aligned up the screw holes, then made the nut recess using a polygon and square. next i added the main body and cut the legs using a half circle.
i did the same for the front, just extended the half circle, and duplicated it, so the slot would align with between the legs.

title: Tevo Tarantula X-Carriage Cable Chain Adapter

description.text:
Well, this is my final version. All I want to add is a cover for the wiring at the top Z mount.

I´ve added Z axis parts as well, because they are needed to add this cable chain.

Tevo Tarantula is my first printer, and I´m in love with it, but it certainly needs improvements here and there. So, to get rid of the cable mess.

It´s for 10x20 mm chain. I´ve decided to buy a chain instead of making it for weight, elasticity and time reasons.

Some comments about the parts:

X-carriage cable chain: It has a hole to front load the wires, and attach to original x-carriage screws. It includes now points to attach wires with zip ties. Just print it in 0.3 mm layers, and 1.2 mm walls. I´ve used supports, and didn´t try without. Printed this now in PLA, and it was hard to remove some supports. PETG or ABS are easier to remove supports.

Z rod top bracket: It was designed to attach the top of the chain. I needed to offset the z axis a little more so the chain would fit. I´ve left an open part to allow me to route the wiring thru aluminum frame, what I´ll do next. There is just a cover missing but it´s usable, and you can design one if you want. Printed with 0.3 mm with supports and 1.2 mm walls. Printed this in PETG, so supports were easier to remove.

Z rod bottom bracket: Made a reinforced version for better precision, and to correct the offset from top Z bracket. Printed this in PETG, with 0.3 mm and 1.2mm walls. I´ve used support on holes, but don´t think it´s necessary.

Printed another chain adapter for theY axis heated bed, that can be found here.

This is the chain used.

I´ve removed the old designs, but will keep it in my computer. If anyone wants it, just ask.

Tevo Tarantula

No

Supports:

Yes

0.3 mm

30%

Notes:

Used ABS, 30 mm/s speed, no fan, 8mm brim.

The V2 I´ve printed in clear PETG, 30 mm/s, 30% fan after second layer, same support, resolution and infill settings. It´s just beautiful.

  • Michelle_Wand_Split: The wand, split in half (tip and base) with a built-in tapered connector peg for easy gluing. Build volume of the split model is 147mm x 31mm x 17mm.
  • Michelle_Wand_Base: Just the base
  • Michelle_Wand_Tip: Just the tip

description.text:
This is a combination Power Supply cover and A/C Switch for an AnyCubic Kossel with the heated bed.

My AnyCubic kit did not come with a power supply safety cover, and only had the flip over connector protection found on most AC/DC power supplies. Furthermore, AnyCubic only provided a direct wired A/C cable that didn't allow me to switch off my printer.

This design allows:

  • Use of a standard IEC Computer power cable
  • Provides A/C Fuse protection
  • Protects the A/C & D/C connection terminals from accidental contact
  • Allows the printer to be switched on/off easily.

The opening on the face is for a press-fit integrated IEC Connector, Fuse, and Switch, like this one on Amazon.

I use this cover in combination with the simplified 2020 Power Supply Mount designed by @BlakeMcCoy

Notes:

Supports are to help with the bridge over the Power Switch location.
If your printer can bridge across the ~50mm span, then don't bother.

description.text: I designed this for my 1/10th Scale redcats nitro buggy as I wanted taller tires that would lift it off the ground. After having printed the original tire out of PLA i found that it made a better drift buggy on concrete so I designed the sleeve for additional traction. Although my printer had an issue when it got to the end with the 90 degree print angle. This worked out though as it made them relatively easy to slide on. The sleeves fit snug and will not move. description.text:
This magnifying glass holder uses a socket which is meant to work with this locking ball and socket system:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:824711

It's for use with a 7.5 cm magnifying glass purchased from a dollar store. The lens was easily extracted from that magnifying glass by using a hacksaw to cut the rim at one location.

WARNING: The 7.5 cm lens is a little on the heavy side for the ball and socket system. Any heavier and it would probably just droop down. That's one reason I came up with the longer ball and socket joint https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2770809. Look closely at my photograph of it in use and you'll see two of these longer joints in use. Fewer joints means fewer places it could droop.

The basic design idea for the ring that holds the lens comes from here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:801279
I made the ring from scratch though, to make it easier to edit the mesh in Blender (I used fewer polygons).

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25 mm

Infill:

60%

Notes:

I've printed it with only PLA. I print it with the socket down on the bed and so it needs support. The raft also helps keep it from falling down. The large amount of infill is for strength.

Note that the OBJ and STL files were exported from Blender. Cura was able to open the OBJ file but not the STL. I assume this is a Blender issue.
To insert the lens, just slide it into one side of the rim first and then into the other side. The rim is flexible enough to do that easily.

description.text:
This is a mod for the PSU to move the Mains power socket to the back of the printer. You may want to do this for a variety of reasons mine was so my printer would fit neatly inside of my enclosure.

Due to a circuit board soldered onto the power socket the mk2 version of this mod is not possible. My solution was to piggy back a small enclosure onto the back of the PSU cover to house the socket and PCB.

Note:

  • AC mains power can be lethal
  • Read all instructions before beginning.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

I used simplify 3d to place supports only where they were needed

1. Remove support material from parts 2. Tap the holes on the flanges for the rear cover 3. Remove the printed cover from the PSU 4. Disconnect the far left wire from the terminal block

This is the terminal with a thick black wire and a thin red wire

5. Disconnect the wires from the power switch and the mains power socket

Take a photo of the socket and where the wires are connected for reference when reassembling.

6. Remove the switch and socket from the cover 7. Make a longer jumper cable for the switch

Using quality heavy gauge wire create a new longer jumper cable to go between the socket and the switch. about 150mm long.

8. Remove the mains socket earth and neutral wires from the terminal block

Again take a photo for future reference.

9. Attach the Earth, Neutral and jumper cable you made to the mains socket and install it in the newly printed part.

placing the nut in the top captive hole and then insert the screw from the other side. DO NOT tight fully yet. place a nut in the lower captive nut hole and insert the screw from the other side. you can now tighten both screws.

10. Attach the mains sock cover onto the PSU cover

thread the wire through the hole in the PSU cover. for not just use one screw in each side to hold the cover in place. DO NOT OVER TIGHTEN!!!

11. Thread the printer wires through the small hole in the PSU cover 12. Press the switch into the cover and attach all the wires onto the switch and terminal block 13. Attach the cover to the PSU using 2 screws 14. Remove the mains socket cover to put the last larger M4 screw in 15. Now fit the Mains socket cover back on and insert all for screws

DO NOT OVER TIGHTEN!!!

description.text:
I've already posted 2 revisions of Z-Axis stabilizer for Velleman Vertex K8400 printer:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1507471
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2518429

The idea of this design came to me after my Z-coupler broke. I replaced it with similar product of another (cheaper) brand and almost immediately mentioned that the print quality is much worse than before. I started looking into the reasons and found two, that could cause both - original coupler breakage and new coupler's poor performance:
1) the weight of build platform. It was already significant from the very beginning and increased even further when I added heated bed
2) during the last few months I did lots of mods to my printer that required me to turn the printer upside down. In this position coupler works as a spring and holds the entire weight of the platform hanging in the air.

To address both issues I decided to modify my Z-axis stabilizer and put the weight of the build platform on 608 bearing. I added 2 spacers and 4 clamps to hold Z-axis in place. I also changed the shape of the parts holding the bearing to make sure the clamps and spacers fit.

After installing this mod the print quality returned, or maybe even exceeded, the one I had while using original coupler from Velleman.

NOTE: The parts published here were designed for my VertexEvo printer, however they should fit the original K8400 as well.

Parts used:

  • 4 x M3x12mm screws
  • 4 x M3x20mm socket cup head screws
  • 4 x M3 self locking nuts
  • 2 x M5x30mm screws (for VertexEvo) or 2 x M5x40mm screws (for original K8400)
  • 1 x 608 bearing (outer diameter 22mm, hole 8mm, height 7mm)

You will need to slightly lift z-rod with build platform and push upper clamps all the way down while tightening them. Make sure Z-coupler is not under pressure. Once upper clamps are fixed in position, push lower clamps all the way up and tighten them there. Don't forget to place spacers between clamps and the bearing. Wider side of each spacer should face its adjacent clamp.

description.text:
Motivated by @madvillain remix of my design, I decided to make numerous improvements to get the design to be very similar size of the original.

In the end the new design is 0.7mm wider and 2mm longer! However, the design will need a printer that has pretty good precision due to the reduction in tolerances in order to achieve the slim design. If your printer has a tendency to overshoot/over-extrude, some cleanup with a file may be required.

The new lever looks weird but it is very deliberate.

The push rod needs to be rotated in, this way there is no glue required.and the button is really secure. See the attached pictures on how to install. A piece of felt is required to prevent the cards from falling out, there is a slot provided for this purpose on the left side of the wallet. I found the best material to use is 3M sticky velcro and using only the fuzzy side (not the hook side).

The optional screw is M3x6(ish) or M2.5x6(ish). The money sheath is included from my previous design for convenience. Scaling the design in the Z direction will allow for more cards but only recommended that only one card be added as the walls increase in height as well.

Enjoy and post pictures of your prints!

EDIT: Added a cover with no screw hole and pushrod updated for smoother action, old pushrod renamed

Printer:

Kossel XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

80

Notes:

To get the surface stippling pattern, I tricked slic3r. I printed the top with only one top layer so it shows the infill layer, the final settings are: 4 lower, 4 perimeters, 30% honeycomb infill and 1 top layer.

The rest of the wallet was printed with 80% infill for strength.

My first online request, from /u/Shavits. They asked for a halfling gunslinger, so I took this as a good time to upgrade my halfling model to a dynamic, posable one. This halfling should work for the type of PC who take performance; pirates, gunslingers, swashbucklers and the like.

This one has a few details set at 0.2 intervals instead of the standard 0.6 intervals, so I'd recommend printing this on 0.2 layers (or 0.1 / 0.04).

28Chibi is a new generation of minis made to be printed flat on the bed. Inspired by the likes of DutchMogul's DungeonDoll's and GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis, These:

  • Print quickly and reliably on high- or low-end printers alike.
  • Are sized for 28mm games such as D&D, Pathfinder, Shadowrun, Starwars EofE etc
  • Storage is space efficient and safe due to the flat-pack & peg-and-hole base design (The peg is 2x2mm, so if the included base is not to your liking adding a slightly larger hole to your preferred base is a quick modification.)
  • The hands are designed for modular equipment, and should generally also accept objects designed in the FlatMini style.

The detail steps up in increments of 0.6mm, allowing for a variety of different layer heights to still print these crisply. 0.2mm is my go to, but higher or lower values (such as 0.1, 0.12, 0.15 or 0.3) all work great too.

comments.text: I don't know how to export that, and it wouldn't be useful anyway. That file contains the g-code instructions which tell the printer how to move and when to extrude filament and all that. It's really hard to turn that back into an editable 3D file, and we generally don't do that. The G-code files are always considered temporary, generated immediately before printing, and only considered valid for that print run. I don't even re-use those files. I always generate a new one, even if I'm printing a second copy of the same model. Small differences in the print run could cause the file to be slightly different each time, and these files are specific to the printer you're using. My file wouldn't work on your printer. It's specifically tuned for my printer.

This is a pretty strange snack bowl with multiple holes for snacks and wavey twisted edges.

The Tests
-A lot of cheaper 3d printers have issues making perfect circles out of the box. This model is designed to test your printer's ability at maintaining accuracy from somewhat small, to somewhat large circles. There are plenty of curves and round surfaces to really test your printer's abilities.

-The secondary test with this model is that of your first layer. This model is designed to be printed with the measurements facing downward, into the build plate. This will test if your first layer is too close (number squished) or too far (looks stringy).

description.text: Just a simple upgrade to the nut that comes with the CR-10 spool mount. It it larger so that the spool slides along smoother. Being round also keeps the spool from catching on corners. It screws on surprisingly well and the bigger radius makes it easy to spin on and off. However, it should be small enough that most spools can be lifted right around it.

Testing.

It is not recommended to 3D print press-fit wheels, because the material is much less robust and does not have as tight of a fit as an injection-molded or machined part. This is a design that attempts to make more reliable 3D printed flywheels using a 6mmx6mm worm gear with a 2mm hole, inspired by mbregg's work here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2769269

The profile of this wheel is similar to Riot, with a 0.5" section of the profile being a concave arc and all sharp points on the contact face filleted. If your printer settings are dialed in correctly, it will fit in a new OFP cage with about 0.02" clearance on the diameter and 0.03" clearance from the floor of the cage.

Outer diameter: 37.6 mm
Root diameter: 33.0 mm

Worm gear fits into the 6mm x 6mm hole and should be glued with plastic welder of some sort.

v2 runs the walls thinner, potentially riskier.
Should print at 80-90% infill for structural integrity, print lower infill at your own risk.

This design has not been tested yet, awaiting worm gears.

======

v3_10 has multiple improvements: Primarily dart alignment fixes, but also experimentally testing a high envelopment wheel setup.

CADded to fit the 41mm OFP cage with a 10mm radius circular hole. This is numerically less squishing/crush than v2 (which was at 9.5mm with a 42.5mm cage), but compresses the dart at a more ideal pressure angle.

9.5 also takes a 41mm cage but has 9.5mm hole.

print_settings.Notes:: I've printed in 0.2mm layer height with 2 perimeters and 40% infill.
