title: Turin Shroud elevated from raw datas
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Turin Shroud has been the subject of 3d elevation by M. Gastineau in 1966 without a computer . Later in 1976, Jumper and Jackson used a vp8 computer to get a 3d elevation from the shroud. I had the opportunity to have the raw datas in 2006 and i cleaned the shroud datas from the tissue chevron using a fft transformation .This is the first time that you have the opportunity to have the final 3d sculpture.
No interpretation was done on the datas, what you print is the man inside the shroud.

This is my second model, the first one had holes. Depending on the interest, i can generate a more detailed model.
NGSS

try to create a shroud using watercolors, on handkerchief paper or tissus The Turin Shroud has been the subject of 3d reconstitutions by M. Gastineau in 1966 without a computer . He used the white and black parts to create a wooden model. It was the first revelation that the shroud not only conserved an image but it also conserved the tree dimensional datas of a real body.Later in 1976, Jumper and Jackson used a vp8 computer to get a 3d elevation from the shroud.It was diplayed on a single green color screen. In 2006 I had the opportunity to have the raw datas and i cleaned the shroud datas from the tissue chevron using a fft transformation .This is the first time that you have the opportunity to have the final 3d sculpture.
No interpretation was done on the datas, what you print is the man inside the shroud.

try to create a shroud using watercolors, on handkerchief paper or tissus add watercolor on the print. Place a white tissue on the sculpture and compare your print to the original shroud. Compare ans examine the differences. compare the proportions and examine why your paper print is larger thant the shroud print. Explain why there are differences and try to explain how the original shroud has been colorized. print without infill, with support and raft. 0.2 layer and 8 cm height is ok 12 cm height is a maximum. The printing is 20min-40 min. The experience can be made in a science classroom or religion classroom, no matter if you are a believer or not.
Watercolor and coton tissus or paper tissus are ok for creating a shroud. the result will be far from the turin shroud whatever you make. The original shroud keeps a 3d data with a verical radiance

description.text:
I dedicate my account to the valorisation of art pieces ,in danger, destructed or underestimated, rarely shown or not avaiable in 3d.

The Sargon mask of the akkadian king is dated 2334–2284 BC, this means it was approximately 5000 years from us . Unfortunately , the Us-Army let the robbers and islamists destruct it in pieces in 2003. Only some pictures remains and the only negatives remaining are in a low format. no 4x5 inches negative exists. This model has been made with photogrametry. the model was just a help for reconstructing it with imagine3d and finalised with lightwave 3d. The model will apperar very small despite it is measured as 36 cm in lightwave so you will have to resize it.

understanding the context Why was it destructed in 2003 ? in the middle of the first iraki war, us soldiers let the robbers do their job. It was broken in pieces by islamists. Why was it in bad condition when it was discoivered not because of the age. The left eye was broken because some people took the eyes- Why was it abandonned? Was in an old city destructed during an akkadian war. Hidden in the ground to preserve it.
understanding the context: -How did it look like ? had eyes and colors how the eyes looked like? colors stones, precious stones -Purpose of the mask ? presence of the king any time

title: Jun Sato's steel structure for NYH House (Yokomizo architects)

description.text:
The real building structure is made out of 9mm thick steel sheets which prevents from bending due to it's curvature.
The scale is set to 1:30 so the walls are 0'3mm thick in the model and can be made with 1 single layer printed. Therefore a good printing quality is requiered to print it correctly, in the pictures you can apreciate how the retraction was not set correctly and small holes appear on the left area of some red walls. The size of the complete model is 90x300x300mm
If you cannot print the walls you can always use a plastic sheet and curve it as I did on the transparent walls version.
The floor slabs have 0.6mm gaps in them in which you can insert the walls and glue them together.

To learn more about Jun Sato's work you can try the following link:
http://junsato.k.u-tokyo.ac.jp/
